SP.L: Give mee a Bagadg that has braines! but Pallatine,
Did not I at first perswade thee, those two
Trim Gentlemen, her Squires, might happily
Mistake the person unto whom the message was
Dispos'd; and that my selfe was hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Thou didst! and thou hast got (Knight) by this hand
I thinke, the Mogul's Neece; shee cannot be
Of lesse discent; the height and strangenesse of
Her port, denote her forraigne, and of great blood!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: What should the Mogul's Neece doe here?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: 'Las thy Eares are buried in a Wool-sack;
Thou hear'st no Newes! 'tis all the voyce in Court,
That shee is sent hither in disguise, to learne
To play on the Gitarh, and make Almond Butter!
But whether this great Lady that I bring
Thee too, be shee; is yet not quite confirm'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Thou talk'st o'th high, and strange comportment that
Thou found'st her in!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Right Sir! she sat on a rich Persian Quilt,
Thridding a Carckanet, of pure, round Pearle,
Bigger than Pidgeons Egges!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: Those I will sell!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Her Maids with little Rods of Rose-marie,
And stalks of Lavander, were brushing Ermines skins;

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: Furres for the Winter! Ile line my Breeches with them!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Her young smooth Pages lay, round at her feet;
Cloath'd like the Sophies Sons; and all at Dice;
The Caster six Wedges a Cubit long
Cries one; another comes a Tun of Pistolets;
And then is cover'd with an Argosie,
Laden with Indico, and Cutchy nill!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: This must be the great Mogul's Neece!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: As for her Groomes, they all were planted on
Their knees, carowsing their great Ladies health
In perfum'd Wines, and then straight quallify'd
Their wild, voluptuous heats with coole Cerbet,
The Turkes owne Iulip?

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Knock, Pallatine!
Quick Rogue! I cannot hold; little thought I
The Thwack's of the North, should inoculate
With the Mogul's of the South!— Pallatine knocks.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Snore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Speake softly Master Constable, I've brought
The very hee Bawd!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Blessing on your heart Sir!
My Watch are above at Trea Trip, for a
Black Pudding, and a pound o' Suffolke Cheese;
They'l ha'done straight: Pray fetch him to mee,
Ile call them downe, and lead him to a by-roome!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: Pallatine, what's he?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: The Ladies steward sir,
A sage Phylosopher, and a grave Pandar!
One that hath writ bawdy Sonnets in Hebrew,
And those so well, that if the Rabbins were
Alive, 'tis thought hee would corrupt their Wives.
Follow mee Knight!—

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Halfe the large Treasure that I get is yours!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: Good faith (my friend) when you are once possess'd
Of all, 'tis as your Conscience will vouchsafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Do'st thou suspect? Ile stay here till thou fetch
A Bible, and a Cushion, and sweare kneeling!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: My Faith shall rather couzen mee; walke in
With this Phylosopher — No words! for hee's
A Pythagorian and Professes silence!
My Ring Master Constable— Snore gives him his Ring, then Exit with Thwack.
Here yet my Reputation's safe! should hee
Have heard of my mischance, and not accompany'd
With this defeat upon himselfe, his Mirth
And Tyranny had beene 'bove humane Sufferance!
Now for the Lady Ample, shee (I guesse)
Lookes on mee with strong fervent Eyes; shee's rich;
And could I worke her into profit, 'twould
Procure my Wit, immortall memory;
But to be gull'd? and by such Trifles too;
Dull, humble Gentlemen that nere drunke Wine,
But on some Coronation day, when each
Conduit pisses Clret at the Towne charge!
Well, though tis worse than Steele or Marble to
Digest; yet I have learnd, one stop in a
Careire, taint not a Rider with disgrace;
But may procure him breath to win the race. Exit.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT. 4. SCEN. 1.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Engine, Meager, Pert, Pallatine richly cloath'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Your Brother's in the house; the Letter which
I sent to tempt him hither wrought above
The reach of our desires; My Lady Sir,
Hee does believe is sicke to death; and all,
In languishment for his deare love.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Pert, and Meager, though you have both good faces,
They must not be seene here; there is below,
A Brother o'mine; whom (I take it) you
Have us'd not overtenderlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: S'light he must needs remember us!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Wee'l sooner stay t'out-face a Basiliske!
Whither shall wee goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: To Snore the Constable: Morglay is still
A Pris'ner in his house; take order for's
Release, as I projected, but (d'you heare)
Hee must not free him till I come.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Pall, will the dull Ruler of the night (Pall)
Obay thy Edict!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall:
SP.L: His wife will, and she's his Constable!
Name mee but to her, and shee does homage!

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: Enough, wee will attend thee there!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: This way Gentlemen. Exeunt Engine, Pert, Meager.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Elder Pallatine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: What's this, an apparition, a Ghost imbroider'd?
Sure he has got the Devill for his Taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.P: Good morrow Brother, Morrow!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: You are in glory sir, I like this flourishing!
The Lilly too, lookes handsome for a Month;
But you (I hope) will last out the whole yeare!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: What flourishing? O Sir, belike you meane
My Cloathes; th'are Ragges, course homely Ragges, beleev't;
Yet they will serve for'th Winter sir, when I
Ride post in Sussex wayes! —

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: This gayetie denotes
Some solitary treasure in the Pocket,
And so you may become a lender too;
You know, I'm farre from home!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.P: I'le lend nothing, but good Counsell, and Witt?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Why, sure, you have no Factors sir, in Delph,
Lyghorne, Aleppo, or'th Venetian Iles,
That by their Traffique can advance you thus;
Nor doe you trade i'th City by retaile
In our small Wares: All that you get by Law,
Is but a dolefull Execution
After Arrest; and for your power in Court;
I know your stockings being on, you are
Admitted in the Presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: What does this inferre Brother?
Men of designe are chary of their Minutes,
Be quicke, and subtile!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: The Inf'rence is
You prosper by my documents; and what
You have atchiev'd must be, by your good Wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: If you had had a Sybill to your Nourse,
You could not (Sir) have aym'd neerer the truth.
I saw your Eares and Baggs, were shut to all
Intents of bounty; therefore was inforc'd
Into this way; and 'twas at first somewhat
Against my Conscience too!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: If not to vex
The zealous spirit in you, I would know why?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Good faith I've search'd Records, and cannot find
That Magna Charta does allow a Subject
To live by his Wits; there is no Statute for't!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Your Common Lawyer was no Antiquary!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.L: And then (credit me Sir) the Canons of
The Church authorize no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: You have met with a dull Civillian too!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Yet Brother, these impediments cannot
Choke up my way; I must still on!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: And you believe the Stories of young heires
Enforc'd to signe at Mid-night to appease
The Sword Mans wrath, may be out-done by you!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: I were unkind else, to my owne good parts!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: And that your Wit has power to tempt from the
Severe, grave Bench, the Aldermen themselves,
To rifle where you please, for Skarfes, Feathers,
And for Race Nags!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.P: It is believ'd Sir, in a trice!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: And that your wit can lead our rev'rend Matrons,
And tefty Widowes of fourscore, to scale
(And in their smocks) for fraile commodities
To elevate your Punke?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: All this Sir, is so easie,
My Faith would swallow't, though t'had a sore throat!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: Give mee thy hand! This day Ile cut off the entaile
Of all my Lands, and dis-inherit thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: Will you Sir? I thanke yee!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: But marke mee Brother; for there's Iustice in't,
Admits of no reproofe; what should you doe
With Land, that have a Portion in your braine,
Above all Legacies or heritage?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.P: I conceive you!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: O to live here, i'th faire Metropolis
Of our great Isle, a free Inheritor
Of ev'ry modest, or voluptuous wish,
Thy young desires can breath; and not oblieg'd
To'th Plough-mans toyles, or lazie Reapers swet;
To make the world thy Farme, and ev'ry Man
Lesse witty than thy selfe, Tennant for life;
These are the glories that proclaime a true
Phylosophie, and Soule, in him that climbes
To reach them with neglect of Fame and Life!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: He carries it bravely! As he had felt
Nothing that fits his owne remorse; but know,
Sir Eagle, th'higher that you flye, the lesse
You will appeare to us, dim sighted Fowle,
That flutter here below. Brother, farewell!
They say, the Lady of this house, groanes for
Your love, the tame sick foole is rich; let not
Your pride beguile your profit! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: I suspect him! Not all the skill I have
In Reason, or in Nature can pronounce
Him free, from the defeat upon my Gold,
And Iewels! 'twas like a Brother! but for
His two Confederates; though I should meet
Them in a Mist, darker than Night, or Southerne Fens
Produce, my Eies would be so courteous sure,
To let mee know them!

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Ample, caried in as sicke in a Couch, Luce, Engine, Ginet.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Roome! More ayre! if heav'nly Ministers
Have leasure to consider or assist
The best of Ladies, let them shew it now!—

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: How doe you Madam? Oh, I shall lose
The chiefe example of internall love
Of gentle grace, and feature, that the world
Did ever shew, to dignifie our Sex!

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Work on! I must stand Sentinell beneath! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: Is her disease growne up to such extremitie?
Then it is time, I seeme to suffer too;
Or else my hopes will prove sicker than shee!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: More cruell than the Panthar on his prey!
Why speake you not? no comfort from your Lips;
You Sir that are the cause of this sad hower!

SP.SPEAKER: Gin.
SP.L: He stands as if his Legs had taken root;
A very Mandrake!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: How comes it (Lady) all these Beauties that
But yesterday did seeme to teach
The Spring to flourish and rejoyce, so soone
Are wither'd from our sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: It is in vaine, t'inquire the reason of
That griefe, whose remedy is past; had you
But felt so much remorse, or softnesse in
Your heart, as would have made you nobly just,
And pittifull; the Mourners of this day
Had wanted then, their Dead to weepe upon!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Am I the cause? forbid it gentle heaven!
The Virgins of our Land, when this is told,
Will raze the Monumentall building, where
My buried flesh shall dwell, and throw my dust
Before the sportive windes, till I am blowne
About in parcels lesse then Eie-sight can
Discerne!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Shee listens to you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: If I am guilty of neglect;
Give me a taste of dutie, name how farre
I shall submit to love! the mind hath no
Disease above recovery, if wee
Have courage to remove dispaire!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: O sir, the pride and scornes, with which you first
Did entertaine my passions, and regard,
Have worne my easie heart away; my breast
Is emptier than mine Eies; that have distill'd
Their Balls to Funerall Dew! It is too late!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Ginet, my feares have in them too much Prophecie,
I told thee shee would nere recover!

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.L: For my poore part, I wish no easier Bed
At night, then the cold grave where she must lie!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Luce, Luce! intreat the Gentleman to sit!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Sit neere her sir! You heare her voyce growes weake!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: That you may see your scornes could not perswade
My love, to thoughts of danger or revenge;
The faint remainder of my breath, Ile waste
In Legacies, and Sir to you, you shall
Have all, the Lawes will suffer me to give!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Who, I? sweet Saint, take heed of your last deeds!
Your bounty carries cunning Murder in't;
I shall be kill'd with kindnesse, and depart
Weeping, like a fond Infant, whom the Nurse
Would sooth, too early to his bed!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Nay Sir, no remedy, you must have all:
Though you procur'd her death; the world shall not
Report; she dy'd beholding to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.P: Goe to her Sir, she'ld speake with you agen!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: Sir, if mine Eies, in all their health and glory,
Had not the power to warme you into Love,
Where are my hopes, now they are dimme, and have
Almost forgot the benefit of light!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: Not love! Lady! Queene of my heart! what oathes
Or execrations can perswade your faith
From such a cruell jealousie!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: I'd have some testimony Sir; if but
T'assure the world, my love, and bounty at
My death, were both conferr'd on one, that shew'd
So much requitall, as declares he was
Of Gentle humane race!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: What shall I doe?
Prescribe mee dangers now, horrid as those
Which Mid-night fires beget, in Citties overgrowne;
Or Winter stormes produce at Sea, and try
How far my love will make mee venture to
Augment th'esteeme of yours!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: That triall of your love which I request
Implies no danger Sir; 'tis not in mee
T'urge any thing, but what your owne desires
Would chuse!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Name it! like eager Mastiffs, chain'd
From the encounter of their game, my hot
Fierce appetite diminisheth my strength!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: 'Tis onely this: for feare some other should
Enjoy you when I'm cold, in my last sleepe;
I would intreat you to sit heare, grow sick,
Languish, and dye with mee!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: How! dye with you! Takes Luce aside.
'Twere fit, you hastned her to write downe all
Shee can bestow, and in some forme of Law:
I feare, shee's mad! her sences are so lost,
Shee'l never find them to her use agen!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: I pray Sir why?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Did you not heare what a fantastick sute
Shee makes, that I would sit and dye with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Does this request seeme strange? you will doe little
For a Lady, that deny to bring her
Onward her last journey; or is't your thrift?
Alas you know, soules travell without charge!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: Her little skull is tainted too!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.P: Is hee not willing Luce?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: My best deare Lady, I am willing to
Resigne my selfe to any thing but death!
Doe not suspect my kindnesse now; In troth
I've businesse upon Earth will hold me here
At least a score or two of yeares; but when
That's done; I am content to follow you!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: If this perswasion cannot reach at your
Consent; yet let mee witnesse so much love
In you, as may enforce you languish, and
Decay, for my departure from your sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Can you doe lesse than languish for her death?
Sit downe here, and begin! true sorrow Sir,
If you have any in your brest will quickly
Bring you low enough!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Alas good Ladies! do you think my languishment
And griefe is to begin upon mee now?
Heaven knowes how I have pin'd, and groan'd, since first
Your letter gave mee knowledge of the cause!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: It is not seene Sir in your face!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: My face! I grant you; I bate inwardly!
I'm scorch'd, and dry'd, with sighing to a Mummie:
My Heart, and Liver are not big enough
To choke a Daw! A Lamb layd on the Altar for
A sacrifice hath much more entrailes in't!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Yet still, your sorrow alters not your face?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Why no, I say! No man, that ever was
Of Natures making hath a face moulded
With lesse helpe for hypocrisie than mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.P: Great pitty Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Though I endur'd the Diet and the Flux;
Lay seven dayes buried up to'th Lips like a
Deceas'd sad Indian in warme sand; whilst his
Afflicted Female wipes his salt foame off
With her owne haire, feeds him with Buds of Guacum
For his salad; and Pulpe of Salsa for
His Bread; I say, all this endur'd, would not
Concerne my face! Nothing can decline that!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Yet you are us'd Sir, to bate inwardly!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: More than heires unlanded, or unjoynter'd Wives.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Engine.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: What shall wee doe? Sir Tirant Thrift's come home!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Sir Tirant Thrift!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: My Ladies Guardian Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: He meets th'expected hower, just to my wish!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: What, hath hee brought a husband for my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: There is a certaine one legg'd Gentleman,
Whose better halfe of limbs is wood; for whom
Kind Nature did provide no hands, to prevent
Stealing; and to augment his gracefulnesse,
Hee's crooked as a Witches Bin!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Is he so much wood?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: So much, that if my Lady were in health,
And married to him, as her Guardian did
Propose, wee should have an excellent generation
Of Bed-staves.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: When does hee come?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: To night if his slow Litter will consent;
For they convay him tenderly, lest his
Sharpe bones should grate together: Sir Pallatine,
I wish you could escape my Masters sight!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Is hee comming hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Hee's at the doore! My Ladies sicknesse was
No sooner told him, but hee straight projects
To proffer her a Will of his owne making!
Hee meanes Sir to be heire of all: if hee
Should see you here, hee would suspect my loyaltie,
And doubt you for some cunning Instrument,
That meanes to interrupt his covetous hopes!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Then Ile be gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: No Sir, hee needs must meet you in
Your passage downe! besides, it is not fit
For you, and your great hopes, with my dependancie
On both, to have you absent when my Lady dyes;
I know you must have all: Sir I could wish
That wee might hide you here! —
Draw out the Chest within, that's big enough
To hold you: it were dangerous to have
My Ladies Guardian to find you Sir! — They draw in a Chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: How! layd up like a brush'd Gowne, under lock
And key! By this good light, not I!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: O Sir, if but to save the honour of
Your Mistris fame, what will hee thinke to see
So comely, and so straight a Gentleman
Converse here with a Lady in her Chamber!
And in a time that makes for hi suspition too,
When hee's from home!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: I hate enclosure, I;
It is the humor of a distress'd Rat!

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.L: It is retirement Sir, and you'l come forth
Agen, so sage!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.P: Sir Pallatine! —

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Your Lady cals Sir, to her, and be kind!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Will you permit the last of all my howers
Should be defil'd with Infamie, proclaim'd
By lewder Tongues, to be unchaste ev'n at
My death? what will my Guardian guesse to find
You here?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: No more, Ile in! but think on't gentle Lady!
First to bate in wardly, and then to have
My outward person shut thus and inclos'd
From day light, and your company; I say
But thinke, if't be not worse than death!— He enters the Chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Locke him up Luce, safe as thy Mayden-head! —

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Tirant Thrift.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Engine, where's my charge Engine, my deare charge?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Sick as I told you Sir, and lost to all
The hope, that earthly med'cine can procure!
Her Physitions have taken their last fees,
And then went hence shaking their empty heads,
As they had left lesse braine than hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Alas poore Charge! come, let me see her Engine!

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: At distance Sir, I pray, for I have heard
Your breath is somewhat sowre, with overfasting Sir,
On Holy-day Eeves!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Ha! what is shee Engine?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: A pure, good soule, one that your Ward desir'd
For love and kindreds sake, t'have neere her at
Her death; shee'l outwatch a long Rush Candle,
And reades to her all night the Posie of
Spirituall Flowers!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Does she not gape for Legacies?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Fye no! there's a Cornelian Ring, perhaps
Shee aimes at, cost Ten Groats; or a wrought Smock,
My Lady made now 'gainst her wedding Sir;
Trifles which Maids desire to weepe upon
With Fun'rall Tales, after a Midnight Possit.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Thou saydst below, shee hath made mee her heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: Of all, ev'n to her Slippers and her Pins!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Luce, me thought Luce, I heard my Guardeans voyce!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: It seemes her senses are growne warme agen;
Your presence will recover her!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Will it recover her, then Ile be gon!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: No Sir, shee'l straight grow cold agen! On! on!
She looks that you would speake to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: Alas poor Charge! I little thought to see
This dolefull day.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Wee all are mortall Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: I've taken care, and labour, to provide
A Husband for thee; hee's in's Litter now,
Hastening to Towne; a fine young Gentleman!
Onely a little rumpled in the womb,
With fals his Mother tooke, after his making.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Death is my husband now! but yet I thanke
You for your tender paines, and wish you would
Continue it in quiet governing my Legacies,
When I am past the power to see it Sir;
You shall enjoy all!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: This will occasion more Church building;
And raising of new Hospitals; there were
Enow before; but Charge you'l have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Ile make Sir one request; which I have hope,
You'l grant in thankfulnesse to all my bounty!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: O deare Charge! any thing! Your Couzen here
Shall witnesse the consent and Act,

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Because I would not have my vanities
Remaine, as fond examples to perswade
An imitation in those Ladies that
Succeed my youthfull Pride i'th Towne: my Plumes,
Fantastick Flowers, and Chaines: my haughty Rich
Embroideries: my gawdy Gownes, and wanton Iewels,
I have lock'd within a Chest!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: There Sir, there the Chest stands.

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.P: And I desire it may be buried with mee!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Engine, take care Engine, to see it done!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: Now Sir, I beseech you leave mee: for 'twill
But make my death more sorrowfull, thus to
Continue my converse with one, I so
Much love, and must forsake at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Alack, alack! bury her to night Engine!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Not Sir, unlesse shee dies. Her Ancestors
Have sojourn'd long here in St. Bartholmewes,
And there's a Vault i'th Parish Church, kept only
For her Family; shee must be buried there.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: I Engine, I, and let mee see; the Church
Thou knowst, joynes to my house, a good prevention
From a large walke; 'twill save the charge of Torch-light.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: What Fun'rall Ghests? the neighbours Sir, will looke
To be invited!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: No more than will suffise
To carry downe the Corps; and thou knowst Engine,
Shee is no great weight.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: And what to entertaine them Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: A little Rose-marie, which thou mayst steale
From th'Temple Garden; and as many Comfits
As might serve to Christen a Watchmans Bastard:
Twill be enough!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: This will not doe! Your Citizen
Is a most fierce devourer Sir of Plums!
Six will destroy as many as can make
A Banquet for an Armie!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: Ile have no more, Engine.
Ile have no more! nor (d'you heare) no Burnt wine;
I doe not like this drinking healths to 'th memory
O'th dead; it is prophane.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: You are obay'd!
But Sir, let mee advise you now to trust
The care, and benefit of all your fate
Presents you in this house, to my discretion;
And get you instantly to horse agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Why Engine, speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: In briefe, you know, that all
The Writings which concerne your Wards estate,
Lye at her Lawyers, fifteene Miles from hence!
Your credit, hee not knowing (Sir) shee's sick,
Will eas'ly tempt them to your owne Possession:
Which, once injoy'd, y'are free from all litigious sutes
His envie might incense her Kindred to!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Enough Engine, I am gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: If you should meet the crooked Lover in
His Litter Sir (as 'tis in your owne rode)
You may perswade him move like a Crab, backward;
For here's no mixture, but with wormes.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: 'Tis well thought on Engine! farewell Engine!
Be faithfull, and be rich! —

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: My breeding and
Good manners Sir, teach mee t'attend your bounty!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: But Engine, I could wish, shee would be sure
To dye too night!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Alas good Soule! Ile vndertake
Shee shall doe any thing to please you Sir! Exit Thrift.

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: Engine, thou hast wrought above the power
Of Accident, or Art!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: If you consider't with a just
And lib'rall braine: first, to prevent
Th'accesse, and tedious visits of the Fiend
His love-sick Monster; and then rid him hence,
Vpon a journey to preserve this house
Empty, and free to celebrate the rest
Of our designes!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: This Engine, is thy Holly-day!— Luce knocks at the Chest.
What hoa! Sir Pallatine, are you within?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: Is Sir Tirant Thrift gone? open Lady! open!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: The Cazement Sir I will, a little to
Increase your witships allowance of aire!— opens a wicket at th'end of the Chest.
But th'troth, for liberty of limbs, you may
As soone expect it in a Gally Sir,
After six Murders and a Rape!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: How, Lady of the Lawne!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Sir Launcelot,
You may believ't, if your discreet faith please;
This Tenement is cheape; here you shall dwell,
Keepe home, and be no wanderer!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: The Pox take mee if I like this! sure when
Th'advice of th'Ancients is but ask'd, they'l say
I am now worse, than in the state of a Bawd!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: D'you know this Lady Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: The Lady Ample!
Her vayle's off too! and in the lusty garb
Of health, and merriment! Now shall I grow
As modest as a snayle that in's affliction
Shrinks up himselfe, and's hornes into his shell,
Asham'd still to be seene.

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: Couldst thou believe,
Thou bearded Babe! thou dull ingenderer!
Male rather in the back, than in the braine,
That I could sicken for thy love? for th'cold
Society of a thin Northerne Wit! — Eld: Pallatine sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: Then Troyains waile with great remorse,
The Greekes are lock'd i'th wooden horse! Enter Yo: Pallatine.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Pall, come in Pall! tis done! the spacious Man
Of Land, is now contented with his owne length.

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.P: Your Brother's come to see you Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pa.
SP.L: Brother! Mad Girles these I couldst thou believ't sirrah!
I am Coffin'd up like a Salmon Pye,
New sent from Den'shire for a token! Come,
Breake up the Chest!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.P: Stay Brother! whose Chest is it?

SP.SPEAKER: El. Pall.
SP.L: Thou'lt aske more questions then a Constable
In's sleepe! prethee dispatch!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Brother, I can,
But marke the Malice and the envy of
Nature: I am no sooner exalted
To rich Possessions, and a glorious meen;
But straight you tempt mee to a forfeiture
Of all; to commit Felony; breake open Chests!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld Pall.
SP.P: O for Dame Patience! the Fooles Mistresse!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Brother, you have prayd well, heaven send her you!
You must forsake your owne faire fertile soyle,
To live here by your Wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: And dreame Sir of
Enjoying goodly Ladies six yards high!
With Sattin Traines behind them ten yards long!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Cloth'd all in Purple, and imbroadred with
Embossements wrought in Imag'ry, the works
O'th ancient Poets drawne into similitude,
And cunning shape!

SP.SPEAKER: Gin.
SP.P: And this attain'd Sir by your Wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Nothing could please your haughty Pallat but
The Muskatelli, and Frantiniak Grape!
Your Turin and your Tuscan Veale, with Red
Legg'd Partridge of the Genoa hils!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: With your broad Liver o'th Venecian Goose;
Fatned by a Iew; and your aged Carpe,
Bred i'th Geneva Lake!

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl. Luce. Ginet.
SP.P: All this maintain'd Sir by your Wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: And then you talk'd Sir of your Snailes t'ane from
The dewy Marble Quarries of Carrara,
And sows'd in Luca Oyle; with Creame of Zwitzerland,
And Genoa pas.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Your Angelots of Brie!
Your Mrsolini, and Parmasan of Lodi!
Your Malamucka Mellons, and Cicilian Dates!
And then to close your proud voluptuous Maw,
Marmalad made, by the cleanely Nunnes of Lisbone!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample. Luce. Ginet.
SP.P: And still thus feasted by your wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Deafned with tyranny! is there no end!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: Yes Sir, an end of you; you shall be now
Convay'd into a closse darke Vault; there keepe
My silent Grandsire company; and all
The Musicke of your groanes, engrosse to your owne eares!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: How! buried, and alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Brother! your hand!—
Farewell! I'm for the North! the fame of this
Your voluntary death, will there be thought
Pure courtesie to me; I meane to take
Possession sir, and patiently converse
With all those Hindes, those Heards, and Flocks,
That you disdain'd in fulnesse of your Wit!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Helpe Pall to carry him! he takes it heavily! —

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: I'le not endur't! fire! murder! fire! treason!
Murder! treason! fire!—

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Alas you are not heard!
The house containes none but our selves! Ex. carying out the Chest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Thwack, Pert, Meager.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: We bring you sir, commends from Pallatine!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: I had as'live, y' had brought it from the Devill!
Together with his hornes boyld to a Ielly,
For a Cordiall against lust!

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.L: We meane the younger Pallatine; one Sir,
That loves your person, and laments this chance,
Which his false brother hath exposde you to!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: And as we told you sir, by his command,
We have compounded with the Constable;
In whose darke house, y'are now a Prisoner!
But sir, take't on my Faith; you must disburse!
For Gold is a restorative, as well
To libertie as health!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: And you beleeve
(It seemes) that your small-tinie Officer
Will take his Unction in the Palme as lovingly,
As your exalted Grandee, that awes all
With hideous voyce, and face!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Even so the Moderns render it!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: But Gentlemen, you aske a hundred pounds;
Tis all I've left!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Sir doe but thinke what a
Prodigious blemish it will be, both to
Your ingenuitie, and fame, to be
Betrayd by one, that is believ'd, no wittier than
Your selfe, and lye imprison'd for a Bawd!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Sir name it not! You kill mee through the eare!
I'd rather Sir, y'ould take my Mother from
Her grave, and put her to doe Pennance in▪
Her winding sheet: there is the Sum! —

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: I'le in Sir, and discharge you! Exit Meager.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: These carnall Mulcts and Tributes are design'd
Onely to such vaine people as have Land;
Are you, and your friend Landed Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Such land as wee can share Sir in the Map!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Lo'you there now! These live by their Wits!
Why should not I take the next Key I meet,
And open this great head; to try, if there
Be any braines left, but sowre Curds, and Plum-broth!
Couzen'd in my Youth! couzen'd in my Age!
Sir, doe you judge, if I have cause to curse
This false, inhumane Towne! when I was young,
I was arrested for a stale commoditie
Of Nut-crackers, long Gigs, and Casting Tops:
Now I am old, imprison'd for a Bawd!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: These are sad Tales!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: I will write downe to'th Country, to dehort
The Gentry from comming hither, Letters
Of strange dire Newes; You shall disperse them Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Most faithfully!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: That there are Lents, six yeares long proclam'd by th'State!
That our French and Deale Wines are poyson'd so
With Brimstone by the Hollander, that they
Will onely serve for Med'cine to recover
Children of the Itch; and there is not left
Sack enough, to mull for a Parsons cold!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: This needs must terrifie!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: That our Theaters are raz'd downe; and where
They stood, hoarse Midnight Lectures preach'd by Wives
Of Comb-makers, and Mid-wives of Tower-Wharfe!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: 'Twill take impregnablie!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: And that a new Plantation Sir (marke me)
Is made i'th Coven Garden, from the Sutlerie
O'th German Campes, and the Suburbs of Paris,
Where such a salt disease regnes as will make
Sassafras dearer than Vnicornes Horne!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: This cannot chuse but fright the Gentry hence;
And more impoverish the Towne, than a
Subversion of their Faire of Bartholmew,
The absence of the Termes, and Court!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: You shall (if my projections thrive) in lesse
(Sir) than a yeare; stable your horses in
The New Exchange, and graze them in the Old!—

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Meager, Queasie, Snore, Mist: Snore.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Iog off! there's Pall, treating for your liberty!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: The Canopy, the Hangings, and the Bed,
Are worth more than your Rent! come, y'are overpaid!
Besides, the Gentleman's betray'd! hee is no Bawd!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Truely, a very civill Gentleman!
'Las, hee hath onely roar'd, and sworne, and curs'd
Since hee was t'ane: no bawdry Ile assure yee!

SP.SPEAKER: Mist: Snor.
SP.P: Gossip Queasie! what a good'yer would ye have?

SP.SPEAKER: Quea.
SP.P: I am content, if you and I were friends!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Come, come agree! 'tis I that ever bleed,
And suffer in your wars!

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Snor.
SP.L: Sweet Master Pallatine, here me but speake!
Have I not often said, Why neighbour Queasie,
Come to my house; besides, your Daughter Mall,
You know, last Pompeon time, din'd with me thrice!
When my childs best yellow stockings were missing;
And a new Pewter Porenger mark'd with P. L.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.P: I for Elizabeth Snore!

SP.SPEAKER: Mist: Snor.
SP.P: The Pewterer that mark'd it was my Uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: Quea.
SP.P: Why, did my Daughter steale your goods?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Snor.
SP.L: You heare me say nothing! but there is
As bad as this (I warrant yee) learn't at
The Back-house! Ile have an Oven o'mine owne shortly!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Come, no more words! there's to reconcile you
In Burnt wine, and Cake! Goe, get you all in!
I'm full of businesse, and strange Mistery!

DIV1.STAGE: Exeunt Snore, Mist: Snore, Queasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.L: A hundred Pall! 'twas all his store; it lies
Here my brave Boy, warme, and secure in Pouch!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Wee'l share't anon.— What need your blush Sir Morglay,
Like a Mayd newly undone in a darke
Entrie? There are disasters sure, as bad
As yours Recorded in the Citie Annals!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Your Brother is a Gentleman of a
Most even, and blessed composition, Sir;
His very blood is made of Holy-Water,
Lesse salt, than Almond-milke!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: My silly reprehension's were dispis'd;
Y'would be his Disciple, and follow him,
In a new Path, unknowne to his owne feet.
Yet I've walk't in it since; and prosper'd as
You see, without or Land, or Tenement.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Tis possible to live b'our Wits! that is
As evident as light, no humane learning
Shall advise me from that Faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Sir Knight, what will you give worthy my braine,
And mee; if after a concealement of
Your present shame, I can advise you, how,
T'achieve such store of wealth, and treasure, as
Shall keepe you here, th'exemplar glory of
The Towne, a long whole yeare, without reliefe
Or charge, from your owne Rents. This (I take it)
Was the whole Pride, at which, some few dayes since,
Your fancie aym'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: This was Sir in the howres
Of haughtinesse and hope! but now—

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Ile do't: whilst my poore Brother too; low, and
Declin'd, shall see, and envie it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Live in full port; observ'd, and wondred at?
Wine, ever flowing in large Saxon Romekins
About my board; with your soft sarsnet smock
At night; and forreigne Musick to entranse?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: All this, and more than thy invention can
Invite thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Ile make thee heire of my
Estate! take my right hand, and your two friends
For witnesses!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Enough! heare mee with haste!
The Lady Ample's dead!— Nay there are things
Have chanc'd since your concealment far more fit
For wonder Sir, than this: Out of a silly piety,
T'avoyd a thirst of Gold, and gawdy Pride
I'th world; sh'ath buried with her in a Chest,
Her Iewels, and her Clothes; besides, as I'm
Enform'd by Luce (my wise Intelligence)
Five thousand pounds in Gold; a Legacie,
Left by her Aunt more than her Guardian knew!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwac.
SP.P: Well, what of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Your selfe, and I, joyn'd Sir in a most firme
And loyall League, may rob this Chest!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: Marrie, and will!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Then when your promise is but ratify'd,
Take all the treasure for your owne expence!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Come let us goe; My fingers burne till they
Are telling it! The night will grow upon's!
Onely you and I, I'le not trust new Faces:
Dismisse these Gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: At the next street Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: This is at least a girne of Fortune, if
Not a faire smile. I'm still for my old Problem;
Since the living rob mee, Ile rob the dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: On my delicious Pert! Now is the time
To make our Purses swell, and Spirits climbe! Exeunt omnes.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT. 5. SCEN. 1.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Ample, Luce, Engine, with a Torch.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Engine, draw out the Chest, and ope the Wicket!
Let us not hinder him the ayre, since tis
Become his food!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld, Pall.
SP.P: Who's there? what are you? speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: A brace of mourning Virgins Sir; that had
You dy'd in Love, and in your Wits, would now
Have brought Roses, and Lillies, Buds of the Brier,
And Summer Pinks to strew upon your Herse!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Then you resolve mee dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: 'Twere good that you would so resolve your selfe!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: She counsells you to wise and severe thoughts;
Why, you are no more mortify'd, then Men
That are about to dance the Morrice!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Ladies, and Brother too (whom I beginne
To worship now, for tendernesse of heart)
Can you believe, I am so leaden, stupid,
And so very a Fish, to thinke you dare
Thus murther me in bravery of Mirth,
You haue gone farre: part of my suff'rance I
Confesse a justice to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: O, doe you so!
Hath your heart, and braine mett upon that point;
And render'd you silly to your owne thoughts!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Somewhat mistaken i'th projection of
My journey hither! Three houres in a Chest
Among the dead; will profit more than three
Yeares in a Study; 'Mongst Fathers, Schoolemen,
And Phylosophers!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.L: And y'are perswaded now, that there is relatiue
To'th maintaining of a poore younger Brother,
Something beside his Witts?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: 'Tis so conceiv'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: And that we Ladies of the Towne, or Court,
Have not such waxen hearts, that ev'ry beame
From a hott Lovers Eie, can melt them through
Our Breasts?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Faith, 'tis imagin'd too!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: That though th'unruly Apetites of some
Perverted few, of our fraile Sex, have made
Them yield their honors to unlawfull love;
Yet there is no such want of you Male-sinners
As should constraine them hyre you to't with Gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Y'have taught me a new Musick, I am all
Consent, and concordance!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: And that, the nimble packing hand, the swift
Disordred shuflle, or the slurr; or his
More base imployment, that with youth, and an
Eternall back, engenders for his bread;
Doe all belong to Men, that may be said
To live sir, by their Sinnes, not by their Witts!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Sir, whom I love not, nor desire to love,
I am of your minde too!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo, Pall.
SP.L: Madame, a faire conversion, 'tis now fit
I sue unto you, for his libertie!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: Alas he hath so profited in this
Retirement, that I feare he will not willingly
Come out!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: O Lady, doubt it not! Open the Chest!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: A litle patience Sir! Enter Ginet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.L: Madam, we are undone, your Guardian is
At dore, knocking as if he meant to wake
All his dead Neighbours in the Church!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.P: So soone return'd! it is not midnight yet!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: I know the bayt that tempts him backe with such
Strange hast; and have according to your will
Provided (Madam) to betray his hopes!

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.P: Excellent Engine!

SP.SPEAKER: Engine.
SP.L: This Key convayes you through the Chancell to
The house Gall'ry! My way lies here; Ile let
Him in, and try how our designe will relish!— Exit Engine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ample.
SP.L: Come sir, it is decreed in our wise Counsell,
You must be layd some distance from this place!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Pray save your labour (Madam) I'le come forth!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: No sir, not yet!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.P: Brother, a cast of your voyce!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: She hath the Key Brother! tis but an howers
Darke contemplation more!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Madam, here me speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: Nay, no beginning of orations now;
This is a time of great dispatch, and hast;
We have more plots then a Generall in a siedge! — Ex. carrying out the Chest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Thrift, Engine.

SP.SPEAKER: Engine.
SP.L: None of the Writings Sir, and yet perplex
Your selfe, with so much speed in a returne!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: The Lawyer was from home, but Engine, I
Had hope to have prevented by my hast,
Though not her Fun'rall, yet the Fun'rall of
The Chest; Ah deare Engine, tell me but why
So much pure innocent Treasure, should be
Thus throwne into a darke forgetfulnesse!

SP.SPEAKER: Engine.
SP.L: I thought, I had encountred his intents!
All Sir, that Law, allow'd her bounty to
Bestow, is yours; but for the Chest; trust me,
'Tis buried sir; the Key is here sir, of no use!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Hah, Engine! Give it me!—

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: And Sir, to vex your meditation more,
Though not with Manners, yet with truth; know there
Is hidden in that Chest, a plenteous heape
Of Gold; together with a Rope of most
Inestimable Pearle, left by her late
Dead Aunt by will, and kept from your discovery!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Is this true, Engine?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: That precise Chit Luce, her couzen Puritan
Was at th'interring of't; conceal'd it till
The Fun'rall formes were past; and then forsooth,
Shee boasted that it was a pious Meanes,
To avoyd covetous desires i'th world▪

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: These Fun'rall tales (Engine) are sad indeed;
Able to melt an Eye, though harder than
That heart, which did consent to so much cruelty
Vpon the harmlesse Treasure!

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: I mourne within Sir too!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: Give mee the Key, that leads me from my house,
Vnto the Chauncell doore!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: Tis very late Sir, whither will you goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Never too late too pray; My heart is heavie!

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: Where shall I wait you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: At my low Gall'ry doore, I may chance stay long.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: This takes mee more than all the kindnesse Fortune
Ever shew'd mee: a desent transmutation.
I am no more your Steward, but your Spie! Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Pert, Meager, Snore, and Watchmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: There, there's more Mony for your Watch; me thinks
Th'ave not drunke Wine enough; they doe not chirpe!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Your Wine mates them, they understand it not.
But they have very good capacity in Ale;
Ale Sir, will heat 'um more than your Biefe Brewis!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: Well, let them have Ale then.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: O Sir, 'twill make 'um sing like the Silk-knitters
Of Cock-lane!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Meager, goe you to Sir Tirant Thrifts house,
Luce, and the Lady are alone, they will
Have cause to use your diligence, make haste!

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: Your dog, ty'd to a Bottle, shall not out-run me! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Pert, stay you here with Master Constable;
And when occasion cals, see that you draw
Your lusty Bill-men forth; bravley advanc'd
Vnder the Colours of Queene Ample, and
My selfe, her Generall!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: If Ale can fortifie, feare not! where's Sir Morglay?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: I'm now, to meet him i'th Church-yard; th'old Blade
Sculks there like a tame filcher, as hee had
Nere stolne 'bove Egges from Market women;
Robb'd an Orchard, or a Cheese loft!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.P: Wee'l wait your worship in this corner.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: No stirring, till I either come, or send.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Pray Sir let's not stay long, 'tis a cold night;
And I have nothing on my Bed at home,
But a thin Coverlet, and my wives Sey Petti-coat:
Shee'l nere sleepe (poore soule) till I come home
To keepe here warme!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: You shall be sent for strait!
Be merry my dull Sons o'th Night, and Chirpe! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Come, neighbour Runlet! sighing payes no Rent,
Though the Land-Lady be in love! Sing out —
SP.STAGE: They sing a Catch in foure Parts.
SP.L: With Lanthorne on Stall; at Trea Trip wee play,

L.HI: For Ale, Cheese, and Pudding, till it be day:
And for our Break-fast (after long sitting)
Wee steale a Street Pig, o'th Constables gitting.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Engine.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Sir, draw downe your Watch into the Church,
And let 'um lie hid close by the Vestrie dore!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Is hee there already?

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Fat Carriers Sir, make not more haste to bed,
Nor leane Phylosophers to rise; I've so
Prepar'd things, that hee'l find himselfe mistaken!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Close by the Vestry dore!

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.L: Right sir,
Ile to my Lady, and expect th'event of your surprise!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Follow Master Constable, one, and one:
All in a File! — Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Thrift, with a Candle.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.L: I cannot find where they have layd her Coffin!
But there's the Chest; Ile draw it out, that I
May have more roome, to search, and rifle it!—
The weight seemes easie to me, though my strength
Be old; how long, thou bright all powerfull minerall,
Might'st thou lie hid, ere the dull dead, that are
Entomb'd about thee here, could reach the Sense,
To turne wise Thieves, and steale thee from oblivion!— opens it, and finds a Halter.
How! a Halter! what Fiend affronts mee with
This Emblem! Is this the Rope of Orient Pearle? —

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Pert, Snore, Watchmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Now I have told you Master Constable,
The intire plot; marke but, how like that Chest,
Is to the other, where the Elder Pallatine
Lies a Perdu; Engine contriv'd them both!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Hah! what are these, the Constable and Watch?

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Ceaze on him for no lesse than sacriledge!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Why neighbors, Gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Wee shall know now, who stole the Wanscot Cover
From the Font, and the Vicar's Surplisse!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Alas grave Sir, become a forfeiture
To'th King, for Sacriledge!

SP.SPEAKER: Thrif.
SP.P: Heare me but speake!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.P: No, not in a cause against the King!

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Lead to's owne house! he shall be Pris'ner there,
And lock'd up safe enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Vndone for ever!— Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Yo: Pallat: Thwack, with an Iron Crow, and dark Lanthorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Why this was such a firke of Piety,
I nere heard of: Bury her Gold with her?
Tis strange her old shooes were not interr'd too;
For feare the dayes of Edgar should returne,
When they coyn'd Leather.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.P: Come Sir, lay down your Instrument!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: I'm so taken with thy free jolly Nature,
I cannot for my heart proceed to more
Defeat upon thy liberty: all that
I told thee were ranke lyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: How! no treasure trovar!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Not so much as will pay for that small Candle light
We waste to find it out!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: I thanke you Sir! — Flings downe the Crow of Iron.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.L: You shall have cause, when you heare more; to this
Darke region Sir, solemne, and silent, as
Your thoughts must be, ere they are mortify'd.
Have I now brought you, to perceive what an
Immense large Asse (under your favour Knight)
You are to be seduc'd, to such vaine stratagems
By that more profound Foppe, your friend, my Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: How had I been serv'd, if I'ad brought my scales
Hither, to weigh this Gold? but on! your brother!
Whose name (let me tell you first) sounds far worse
To me then does a Sergeant to a young
Indebted Lover, that's arrested in his Coach,
And with his Mistris by him!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: You are believ'd: but will you now confirme
Me to your grace and love, if I shall make't
Appeare, that in a kind revenge of what
You suffred Sir, I've made this false, and great
Seducer of Mankind, to suffer more.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: The Legend, Talmud, nor the Alcharon,
Have not such doubtfull tales as these; but make't
Appeare, I would have evidence!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Then take't on my Religion Sir, he was
Layd up in durance for a Bawd before
He betrayd you to the same preferment!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Shall this be justify'd, when my disgrace
Comes to be knowne; wilt thou then witnesse it?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: With a deepe oath! And Sir, to tempt more of
Your favours on poore mee, that ever mourn'd
For all your sufferings; know you shall now
See him inclos'd in a blind Chest; where hee
Lies bath'd Sir, in a greater swet than ere
Cornelius tooke in his owne Tub!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Here amongst Sepulchers, and mallencholy bones:
Let mee but see't; and I will dye for joy,
To make thee instantly my heire!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.L: You shall; and yet ere the Sun rise, find him
Enthrall'd too in a new distresse!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Do'st want money? bring mee to Parchment and
A Scriv'ner, Ile seale out two pound of Wax.— Yo. Pall: knocks at the Chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.P: You Sir, my neer'st Ally, are you asleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.P: O Brother, art thou come! quick, let me forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Here is a certaine friend of yours presents
His loving visit Sir!— Opens the Wicket.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Sir Morglay Thwack?
I had rather have seene my sister naked!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: What, like a bashfull Badger doe you draw
Your head into your hole agen? Come sir,
Out with that sage Noddle, that has contriv'd
So cunningly for me, and your deare selfe!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Here, take my Eielids Knight, and sow'em up,
I dare not see thy face!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: But what thinke you
Of a new Iourney from the North, to live
Here by your Wits; or midnight visits sir,
To the Mogols Neece!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: I have offended Knight!
Whip me with wire, headed with Rowels of
Sharpe Ripon Spurs! Ile endure any thing
Rather than thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Wee have (I thanke your bounteous braine)
Beene entertain'd with various consorts sir,
Of whispring Lutes, to sooth us into slumbers,
Spirits of Clare to bathe our Temples in,
And then the wholsome wombe of woman too,
That never teem'd, all this for nothing sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: Come, Ile let him forth!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Rogue! if thou lov'st me!
Nay, let him be confin'd thus, one short moneth!
Ile send him downe to Countrey Faires for a
New motion made, b'a Germane Ingener!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: 'Las, he is my Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Or for a solitary Ape,
Lead captive thus by th' Hollander, because
He came aloft for Spaine, and would not for the States!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Sir Morglay leave your Lanthorne here, and stay
My comming at yon dore; Ile let him out!
But for the new distresse, I promis'd on
His person, take it on my manhood sir,
He feeles it strait!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.P: Finely ensnar'd agen, and instantly!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: Have a good faith, and goe! Exit Thwack.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Deare Brother, wilt thou give me liberty!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Vpon condition sir, you kisse these Hilts,
Sweare not to follow me, but here remaine
Vntill the Lady Ample shall consent,
To'th freedome I bestow!— He kisses the Hilts.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Tis done! a vow inviolate! He opens the Chest and lets him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Now silence Brother! not one curse, nor thankes—

DIV1.STAGE: Exit Yo▪ Pall.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: Fate, and a good Starr speed me! though I have
Long since amaz'd my selfe e'ne to a Marble,
Yet I have courage left, to aske, what this
Might meane? Was ever Two legg'd Man thus us'd!—

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Pert, Snore, & Watchmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Pall, and his friend are gone, I must not stay
His sight; but after you have ceaz'd upon him
Lead him a Prisoner to the Lady too. — Exit Pert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sno.
SP.P: Warrant ye, though he were Gog, or Heldebrand!— they lay hold on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal:
SP.P: How now? What meane you Sirs?

SP.SPEAKER: Snore.
SP.P: Yield to the Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: 'Tis yielded sir, that you are Constable!
But where have I offended!

SP.SPEAKER: Snore.
SP.L: Heere Sir, you have committed Sacriledge,
And robb'd an Aldermans Tombe, of himselfe,
And his Two Sonnes kneeling in Brasse!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.P: How, Flea Monuments of their Brazen skinnes?

SP.SPEAKER: Snore.
SP.L: Looke, a Darke Lanthorne, and an Iron Crow!
Fine evidence for a Iurie!—

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.L: I like this plott! The Lady Ample and
My Brother, have most rare, triumphant Witts;
Now by this hand, I am most eagerly
In love with both; I finde I have deserv'd all;
And am resolv'd t'hugge them, and their designes;
Though they afflict me more, and more! Whither must I goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Snore.
SP.L: Away with him! Saucie fellow! examine
The Kings Constable▪ — Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Young Pallatine, Thwack, Ample, Luce, Meager.

SP.SPEAKER: Meager.
SP.L: I am become your Guardians Iaylor, Lady;
Hee's safe lock'd in the Parlor, and there howles
Like a Dogg that sees a Witch flying!

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: I long to heare how my wise Tutor thrives
I'th new defeat!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: 'Tis well you are converted!
Beleev't that Gentleman deserves your thankes.

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Lady seale my conversion on you Lipp;
'Tis the first leading Kisse, that I intend
For after chastetie!— kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.L: Luce, see you make the proposition good
Which I shall give my Brother from this Lady,
Or Ile so swaddle your small Bones.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Sweet Pall, thou shalt. Madam, you'l please to stand
To what I lately mention'd to your owne desire?

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: To ev'ry particle, and more. — Enter Pert.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Your Brother's come; this roome must be his prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: 'Way Luce, away: stand in the Closet Madam,
That you may heare us both, and reach my call.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: Ile stay, and see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: No Knight; you are decreed Sir Tirants Iudge:
Goe that way Sir, and force him to compound.

SP.SPEAKER: Thwack.
SP.L: Ile fine him soundly,
Till's Purse shrink like a Bladder in the fire▪— Ex. Amp. Luc. Thw. Meag. Pert.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Snore, Elder Pallatine.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Here Sir, this is your Iayle, too good for such
A great Offender.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Sacriledge! very well.
Now all the Pulpit Cushions, all the Hearse Clothes,
And winding sheets, that have been stolne about
The Towne this yeare, will be laid to my charge!

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Pray leave us Master Constable, and looke
Vnto your other Bondman in the Parler. — Exit Snore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: This is the wittiest off-spring that our name
Ere had: I love him beyond hope, or lust,
My Father was no Poet sure, I wonder
How hee got him?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pal.
SP.P: I know you curse me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.P: Brother, introth you lie, and who ere believes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Indeed you doe: Conjurers in a Circle,
That have rais'd up a wrong spirit, curse not
So much, nor yet so inwardly.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.P: I've a great mind to kisse thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.P: You have not sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: I shall do't, and eate up thy lips so far,
Till th'ast nothing left to cover thy teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: And can you thinke all the afflictions you
Endur'd, were merited; first, for misleading
Morglay, your old friend; then, neglect of mee,
And haughty over-vallewing your selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: Brother, I murmur not; the Traps that you
Have layd, were so ingenious, I could wish
To fall in them agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: The Lady Ample Sir,
There is the great contriver that hath weav'd
These knots so intricate and safe: 'Las, I
Was but her lowly Instrument.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Ah that Lady! were I a King, shee should
Sit with me under my best Canopie,
A silver Scepter in her hand; with which,
I'd give her leave to breake my head for ev'ry fault
I did commit.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: But say, I bring this Lady Sir, unto
Your lawfull sheets; make her your bosome wife:
Besides, the plenty of her heritage,
How would it sound, that you had conquer'd her
Who hath so often conquer'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pall.
SP.P: Deare Brother, no new plots.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo. Pall.
SP.L: Six thousand pounds Sir is your yearly Rent;
A faire temptation to a discreet Lady:
Luce, hath fill'd both mine Eares with hope; besides,
I heard her say, shee nere should meet a man,
That she could more subdue with Wit, and Government.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: That Ile venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: Well, my first bounty is your freedome Sir;
For'th Constable obayes no Law, but mine.
And now, Madam! Appeare! — Enter Ample, Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Y'are welcome 'mongst the living Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld, Pal.
SP.L: Lady, no words; if y'have but so much Mercie
As could secure one that your Eies affect.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Why, you'r growne arrogant agen: d'you thinke
They are so weake, to affect you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eld. Pal.
SP.L: I have a heart so kind unto my selfe,
To wish they could; O we should live.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Not by our Wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: No, no! but with such soft content; still in
Conspiracie, how to betray our selves
To new delights, keepe harmonie, with no
More noyse, than what the upper motions make;
And this so constant too, Turtles themselves,
Seeing our faith, shall slight their owne, and pine
With jealousie.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Luce, the youth talkes sence now, no Med'∣cine for
The braine, like to captivity in a darke Chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: O Madam, you are cruell!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Well my sad Convertite: joy yet at this:
I've often made a vow, to marry on
That very day my Wardship is expir'd:
And two howres since, that liberty begun.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Nay, heare her out! your wishes are so sawcie Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: And know, my glory is dispatch. My Ancestors
Were of the fierie French, and taught me love,
Hot eagernesse, and haste!

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Let mee be rude
A while; lye with your judgement, and beget
Sages on that! My dearest, chiefest Lady!—

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.P: Your braine's yet fowle, and will recoyle agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld▪ Pall.
SP.P: No more: Ile swallow downe my Tongue!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: If Sir, your nature be so excellent,
As your kind Brother hath confirm'd to Luce.
And mee; follow, and Ile present you straight
With certaine writings you shall seale to, hood-winck'd,
And purely ignorant of what they are?
This is the swiftest, and the easiest test,
That I can make of your bold love; doe this,
Perhaps, I may vouchsafe to marrie you▪
The writings are within.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: Lead mee to triall, come!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: But Sir, if I should marry you; it is
In confidence, I have the better Wit;
And can subdue you still to quietnesse,
Meeke sufferings, and patient awe.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.P: You rap me still anew.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: In Luce, our hopes grow strong, and Giantly! Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Thrift, Snore, Mist: Snore, Queasie, Ginet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ginet.
SP.L: To him Mistrisse Snore; 'tis hee has kept
Your Husband from his Bed so long, to watch
Him for a Church Robberie!

SP.SPEAKER: Mist: Snor.
SP.L: Ah, thou Iudas! I thought what thou'ldst come to!
Remember the Warrant thou sent'st for mee
Into Duck-lane, 'cause I call'd thy Mayd Trot!
When I was faine t'invite thy Clerke to a
Fee Pye, sent me b'a Temple Cooke, my Sisters Sweet-heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Quea.
SP.L: Nay, and remember who was brought to bed
Under thy Coach house wall; when thou deuid'st
A wad of straw, and wouldst not joyne thy halfe-penny
To send for Milke, for the poore Chrisome!

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Now you may sweeten me with Sugar-loaves
At New-yeares-tide, as I have you Sir. —

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Wee'l teach you to rob Churches! S'light, hereafter
Wee of the Pious shall be afrayd to goe
To a long Exercise, for feare our Pockets should
Be pick'd! Come Sir, you see already how
The neighbours throng to find you; will you consent?
Tis but a thousand pounds a piece to these
Two Gentlemen; and five hundred more t' Engine.
Your crime is then conceal'd, and your selfe free.

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: No, he may chuse, hee'l trust to'th kind hearted Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.L: Let him, and to Dame Iustice too, who though
Her Ladiship be blind, will grope hard Sir,
To find your Money Bags.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.L: Sir you are rich▪ besides, you know what you
Have got by your Wards death; I feare you will
Be begg'd at Court, unlesse you come off thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: There is my Closet Key, doe what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Engin.
SP.P: Gentlemen, Ile lead you to it, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: D'you use to find such sums as these beneath
An Oke, after a long March; I thinke sure,
The wars are not so plentifull.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Wee thinke so too.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Y'had better traile a Bodkin, Gentlemen,
Under the Lady Ample, than a Pike
Under a German Generall.

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.P: Wee'l in for th'Mony Sir, and talk anon. Ex. Eng. Per. Meag.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Eld: Pallatine, Yo: Pallatine, Ample, Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: Sir Tirant Thrift, here is your Ward come from
The dead, t'indite you for a Robbery
Upon her Ghost.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Hah! Is shee alive too?

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Yes, and her Wardship out, before y'have profer'd her
A Husband Sir; so the best benefit
Of all your Guardianship is lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Ampl.
SP.L: In seven long yeares you could not Sir provide
A man deform'd enough, to offer mee
For your owne ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Thrift.
SP.P: Couzen'd of wealth, of fame! Dog Engine! Ex. Thrift.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: Wee must have you enclos'd agen: y'are very
Forward with the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: I will be Sir,
Vntill shee groane! this Priest stayes some what long.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: How's this? troth I shall forgive thee then heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: I've t'ane him i'th behalfe of health; to chide
And jeere, for recreation sake, 'twill keepe
Mee Sir, in breath, now I am past growing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Hearke Knight! here's rellish for your eares. I chose
None of your dull Country Madams, that spend
Their time in studying Receipts, to make
March-Pane, and preserve Plums; that talke
Of painfull Child-births, Servants wages, and
Their husbands good Complexion, and his Leg!

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.P: New wonders yet!

SP.SPEAKER: El: Pall.
SP.L: What was that (Mistris) which I seal'd to, hood-wink'd?
A simple triall of my confidence and love.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Your Brother has it, tis a gift to him
Of one faire Mannor, 'mongst those many that you
Have in Possession Sir; and in this Bond,
Y'are witnesse to three thousand pounds I give to Luce!

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Yes Sir, for Pall and I must marry too.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: I were an Ev'nuch else, and th'world should know't.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: Thou couldst not have betrayd mee to a bounty
I more love. Brother! Give thee joy!— Thw. takes Yo: Pall. aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Thw.
SP.L: You are the cause of all these Miracles:
Therefore I desire you to be my heire;
By this good day you must: for I've t'ane order,
Though I love your Wit, you shall not live by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.P: My kind thanks Sir, the poore Mans gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist: Snor.
SP.L: 'Give you joy sweet Master Pallatine, and
Your Brother too.

SP.SPEAKER: Quea.
SP.L: And send you more such wives,
Ev'ry yeare as many as shall please heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Snor.
SP.L: Tis day. Ile not to bed Sir now; my watch
Shall be drunke, at your worships wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: They shall, and there is Gold enough to keepe
Them so, untill thy reigne be out.—

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Pert, Meager, Engine, with Money Bags.

SP.SPEAKER: Pert.
SP.P: Loaden with composition Pall.—

SP.SPEAKER: Meag.
SP.P: Tis for your sake wee grone under these burdens. —

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pall.
SP.L: The Offall of Sir Tirants Trunks! Brother,
Pray know these Gentlemen, they owe you more
Money than they meane to pay now.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pal.
SP.L: I remember 'um: But no words my Cavalliers,
And you are safe. Where shall we dine to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Yo: Pal.
SP.L: At Lucy's Aunts; wee'l make her costive Beldamship
Come off; when shee beholds a goodly joynture,
And our faire hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Eld: Pall.
SP.L: First, to the Church. Lady,
Ile make your skittish person sure. Some of
Your pleasant Arts upon mee, may become
A wise Example, and a Morall too;
Such as their haughty fancie well befits,
That undertake to live here by their Wits. Exeunt omnes.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGVE.
DIV1.L: THe office of an Epilogue, is now
To smooth &▪ stroke the wrinckles frō each brow;
To guide severer judgements (if wee could
Be wise enough) untill they thought all good,
Which they perhaps dislike; And sure, this were
An over-boldnesse, rais'd from too much Feare.
You have a Freedome, which wee hope you'l use,
T' advance our youthfull Poet, and his Muse
With a kind Doome; And hee'l tread boldly then
In's best new Comick Socks, this Stage agen.
